body: Me too. 'Device' could work with or without streamSync. 'local_allreduce_device' cannot work in either setting.
@piiswrong You can try the C++ example "image-classification-predict.cc". GPU memory will not be released after MXPredFree().
@HrWangChengdu Looks like caffeop is fine. It's local_allreduce_device that's broken @tqchen

mx.recordio.MXRecordIO
LGTM

@antinucleon @mli  i found a  a potential problem of mx.io.ImageRecordIter --> **when set rand_crop = True, then during each epoch the cropped  area of the same image is the same.**, (wish i'm wrong..)  

if this is a bug, then it will influence the resnet result, because our training rec is 480, and for the same image in each epoch, it only see the same area, so the scale augment does't work at all. 

we can reproduced this like this:

``` python
    train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(...)  # set random_crop=True, data_shape less than the size of .rec
    import numpy as np
    import cv2
    for i in range(10):
        X = train.getdata().asnumpy()[i]
        X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 2)
        X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 1)
        X = cv2.cvtColor(X, cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR)
        cv2.imwrite("{}_result.jpg".format(i), X)
        print "image_{}--->{}".format(i, train.getlabel().asnumpy()[i])
    train.reset()
    for i in range(10):
        X = train.getdata().asnumpy()[i]
        X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 2)
        X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 1)
        X = cv2.cvtColor(X, cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR)
        cv2.imwrite("{}_reset_result.jpg".format(i), X)
        print "reset_image_{}--->{}".format(i, train.getlabel().asnumpy()[i])
    train.reset()
    for i in range(10):
        X = train.getdata().asnumpy()[i]
        X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 2)
        X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 1)
        X = cv2.cvtColor(X, cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR)
        cv2.imwrite("{}_reset2_result.jpg".format(i), X)
        print "reset2_image_{}--->{}".format(i, train.getlabel().asnumpy()[i])
```

then the corresponding image is the same. 
the same phenomenon may happen with random mirror.  

but when i debug into https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/io/image_aug_default.cc#L241, i print out the y and x and found it should changed after each epoch.  
could anybody verify this?
#2111 as a reference.

i just test that rand_mirror has the same problem.  so all random parameter in mx.io.ImageRecordIter() may suffer the same thing.

http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/how_to/smart_device.html

you didn't call train.next() so it's always the same batch of data...
The bellow code gives correct result

```
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np
import cv2

train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = '/archive/imagenet/train.rec',
        data_shape  = (3, 224, 224),
        batch_size  = 10,
        rand_crop   = True,
        rand_mirror = True)  # set random_crop=True, data_shape less than the size of .rec
train.reset()
data = train.next().data[0].asnumpy()
for i in range(10):
    X = data[i]
    X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 2)
    X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 1)
    X = cv2.cvtColor(X, cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR)
    cv2.imwrite("{}_result.jpg".format(i), X)
    print "image_{}--->{}".format(i, train.getlabel().asnumpy()[i])
train.reset()
data = train.next().data[0].asnumpy()
for i in range(10):
    X = data[i]
    X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 2)
    X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 1)
    X = cv2.cvtColor(X, cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR)
    cv2.imwrite("{}_reset_result.jpg".format(i), X)
    print "reset_image_{}--->{}".format(i, train.getlabel().asnumpy()[i])
train.reset()
data = train.next().data[0].asnumpy()
for i in range(10):
    X = data[i]
    X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 2)
    X=np.swapaxes(X, 0, 1)
    X = cv2.cvtColor(X, cv2.COLOR_RGB2BGR)
    cv2.imwrite("{}_reset2_result.jpg".format(i), X)
    print "reset2_image_{}--->{}".format(i, train.getlabel().asnumpy()[i])
```

it maybe that when useing im2rec, shoud set color=0 or -1, or it will force your gray image as rbg image.

another small potential problem is that every time we start our program, the result is the same, it may not influence so much but if we change lr manual and retrain the model, then the randomness is the same each time.

So after looking into this a bit more in detail, here are my thoughts and maybe we can find a way to make this easier during the way to 1.0

To compile a julia function as a kernel, I need type information for that function. In most cases we will want to pass in DeviceArrays that use data from NDArrays. These DeviceArrays are parameterized, by DType and NDims. For each signature combination of DType and NDims I need to compile a new kernel. 

This means that `InferShape` and `InferType` need to have run already before I can initialise the PTX, that then get's translated into a `CUmodule` and `CUfunction` optimized per device and then run. 

I then need to communicate that information from a safe point (preferably a synchronous call, async might work but requires a lot more work and is fragile). The current outline of how this might look like can be seen at https://github.com/vchuravy/JLNDArrayOp .
Tomorrow I am going to write the Julia side of this and making it more safe (there are some unsafe hacks in there right now.)

Any feedback would be welcome.

@antinucleon Is it just the legacy codes of padding? I remember that caffe fixed this issue long long ago. In the latest caffe, they use the same infershape as ours. Please help me confirm this since it is related to the core codes.

BTW, the name CAFFE_CONV_COMPATIABLE is not acceptable since it also changes the way of pooling.

Unlike MKL, NNPACK is not x86-only: it now includes kernels implemented with [Clang vector extensions](http://clang.llvm.org/docs/LanguageExtensions.html#vectors-and-extended-vectors). The implementation was originally developed for PNaCl port of NNPACK, but can be compiled to any clang-supported architecture; LLVM will automatically lower the vector operations to the SIMD ISA of the target. To build NNPACK with portable SIMD implementation instead of x86-64 assembly, configure with `python configure.py --enable-psimd`. On Haswell+ targets, however, performance would be about 4 times slower than with x86-64 assembly.

I think we should keep this behavior for now, reproduciblity is quite important, we can, however, enable a global seed that can be seeded through some functions and allow user to pass in the time seed

@freddycct @pluskid 
Here is what I am doing:

I am making a mask LSTM symbol. For each input, we need a data and a mask. The mask will set output to 0 if it is masked as padding. So in general it looks like:

![untitled presentation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1258974/17600063/c191fdba-5fb6-11e6-8686-de18ac477520.jpg)

I am writing a C++ mask op. The mask op will mask output and gradient to original or 0.

@antinucleon thanks! i think what you have is great! Do you think the same mask layer can be used at the outputs? That way, then it will help to model RNN regression with variable output sequence length too.

@Azure-Vani Agreed. You could look at our new [module API](http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/module.html), parameters like `num_epoch` are now in the `fit` function instead of the constructor of the model.

+1 is probably reserving a special symbol for zero-padding. If you break your data into equal length chunks, there is no need for padding. But if you use variable-length sentence, and use Bucketing, probably you will need an extra symbol for padding.
You can wrap torch's io in a torch module

This is a little tricky. I also met this once.

The problem is you are using gcc4.9 with cuda, but your opencv is built using gcc5. You can't link at the last step.

You can try to set gcc5 in `config.mk` and `make`
@zhangjiulong , ./configure --shared is necessary. If you don't do that, there is no shared lib to call.

See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/metric.R for examples.

gradient scale in softmaxoutput is for weighting loss functions if you have multiple of them.

gradient scale in optimizer is for normalizing against batch_size.

They are in effect multiplied togather in the end.

@piiswrong Thanks for your reply, but I still got a little bit confused because in the document, SoftmaxOutput has a "normalization" argument. It says the default is "null", which means nothing will be done. "batch" means  "op will normalize gradient by dividing batch size", while "valid" means " op will normalize gradient by divide sample not ignored". 
I have 2 questions:
1. Does this have the same effect if I set this to "null" and set an appropriate grad_scale?
2. Does "valid samples" mean all samples or only samples in a batch? For example, I have a multi-output softmax, say (2, 3, 100), which mean batch size=2, channel=3 and sample=100. If I set "batch", it divides by 2, right? If I use "valid" does it divide by 100? or (2x100)? If true, does it mean I dont need to change the gradient scale anymore and leave them to default 1.0?
I think this is really important to know if I want to make sure the training is under control. Thanks.

@tqchen @winstywang user can pass `seed` by itself indeed, but currently the `seed` option is only used in shuffle, i.e. `rnd_`, not used for any others image augmentation, i.e. `prnds_`.so should we bring in another seed in ImageRecParserParam(this may puzzled the user)? or change the code to make `ImageRecParserParam` and `ImageRecordParam` share the same seed?
